DataElement.preferredName: Laboratory Procedure Beta-2-Microglobulin Protein Outcome Specified Upper Limit of Normal Value
DataElement.preferredDefinition: the value, in mcg/ml, for the upper level of normal of the medical procedure that involves testing a sample of blood for beta-2 microglobulin, an 11-kDa protein associated with the outer membrane of many cells including lymphocytes, is generally required for the transport of class I heavy chains from the endoplasmic reticulum to the cell surface, and is present in small amounts in serum, csf, and urine of normal people, and to a much greater degree in the urine and plasma of patients with tubular proteinemia, renal failure, or kidney transplants.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: information related to the result of the medical procedure that involves testing a sample of blood for beta-2 microglobulin, an 11-kDa protein associated with the outer membrane of many cells including lymphocytes, is generally required for the transport of class I heavy chains from the endoplasmic reticulum to the cell surface, and is present in small amounts in serum, csf, and urine of normal people, and to a much greater degree in the urine and plasma of patients with tubular proteinemia, renal failure, or kidney transplants.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A procedure for critical evaluation; a means of determining the presence, quality, or truth of something.

Concepts.definition: Any procedure that involves testing or manipulating a sample of blood, urine, or other body substance in a laboratory setting.

Property.preferredDefinition: Beta-2-microglobulin protein (119 aa, ~14 kDa) is  encoded by the human B2M gene. This protein plays a role in immune  responses and is a key component of major histocompatibility complex  class I molecules. The protein is localized to the surface of cells and  is utilized as a prognostic marker in persons with cancers that involve  white blood cells. The polypeptide is also used as a marker in kidney  damage diagnosis and in the detection of viral infection.:Outcome; a phenomenon that follows and is caused by some previous phenomenon.

Concepts.definition: Beta-2-microglobulin protein (119 aa, ~14 kDa) is encoded by the human B2M gene. This protein plays a role in immune responses and is a key component of major histocompatibility complex class I molecules. The protein is localized to the surface of cells and is utilized as a prognostic marker in persons with cancers that involve white blood cells. The polypeptide is also used as a marker in kidney damage diagnosis and in the detection of viral infection.

ValueDomain.preferredName: Beta-2 Microglobulin Specified Upper Limit of Normal Value
ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: the value for the upper level of normal range of a patient's beta-2 microglobulin.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: The top value of the range of statistical characteristics that are supposed to represent accepted standard, non-pathological pattern for particular laboratory result or other quantitative parameter.:A numerical quantity measured or assigned or computed.

Concepts.definition: The top value of the range of statistical characteristics that are supposed to represent accepted standard, non-pathological pattern for particular laboratory result or other quantitative parameter.
A numerical quantity measured or assigned or computed.

ReferenceDocuments.name: -COMMENT
ReferenceDocuments.description: Add instruction: mcg/ml (Note: Record institutional limits of normal)
